column4: So just when I think I have a handle on .bashrc vs .bash_profile and login vs interactive shells, Ubuntu has some trickiness where it always runs .bashrc as long as .bash_profile isn't set - but NOT /etc/profile... can anyone point me at an accurate, up-to-date doc on what runs when?
#basj
no, Ubuntu is going beyond what vanilla bash loads
i dont think ubuntu patched the bash about that feature but ok
I'm sure they didn't patch it, they just have some, er, patchwork of scripts that ends up running .bashrc even for interactive shells
bashrc is always executed for interactive shells
that is not ubuntu-specific
Ubuntu's own man page says "When an interactive shell that is not a login shell  is  started,  bash reads  and  executes  commands  from /etc/bash.bashrc and ~/.bashrc, if these files exist."
yes, and?
that is the bash-default
and not ubuntu-specific
yes, and.. that is not what actually happens.
on Ubuntu, if .bash_profile is not present, an interactive login shell will run .bashrc as well.
any errors on "source ~/.bashrc"?
no, it runs fine. even when the docs say it doesn't run... again, the man page says .bashrc is for interactive NON-login shells, but it runs for interactive YES-login shells as well
hm, imo running bashrc on the logonshell (tty1) is the default on every GNU/Linux
maybe that's true for modern bash, and it's just the man page that's wrong
I know at one point a few years ago I was shocked that there was NO single file that was guaranteed to get loaded in all four combinations (interactive vs non, login vs non)
yes maybe, i am not using bash here and my shell is acting a little different
maye have a look at #bash if they have another idea for that case
Can I blame you for my favorite HP-UX bug?
its sad but we are using AIX instead of HP-UX.......
